H0.text: Higher levels of oxygen in the atmosphere can best explain the approximately 1 °C increase in Earth's average surface temperature over the past century.

H1.text: Lower levels of ozone in the atmosphere best explain the approximately 1 °C increase in Earth's average surface temperature over the past century.

H2.text: Higher levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere can best explain the approximately 1 °C increase in Earth's surface temperature over the past century.

H3.text: Lower levels of nitrogen in the atmosphere are the best explanation for the approximately 1 °C increase in Earth's average surface temperature over the past century.

A4.text: Earth's atmosphere now has roughly 50% more carbon dioxide, the main gas driving global warming, than it did at the end of the pre-industrial era, reaching levels not seen for millions of years.

A5.text: The modern-day rise in global temperatures is driven by human activities, especially fossil fuel (coal, oil and natural gas) burning since the Industrial Revolution.
